scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. Previously, when one of the team members, Alex, said, 'This is impossible! We can't get this done in time,' you responded by encouraging the team to stay focused and work together. Now, during a team meeting, [Monica] slams her pen on the table and adds, 'Even if we try our best, there's no way we can meet this deadline.' [Bob] nods in agreement, looking equally concerned. You acknowledged Monica's feelings and suggested a pragmatic approach to prioritize work. The tension is still high.
scenes.description: [Bob] then leans back in his chair, crossing his arms, and says, 'Prioritizing won't change the fact that we’re understaffed and overworked. What’s the point?'

options.text: Bob, I get where you're coming from. Let’s discuss possible ways to bring in additional help or resources to alleviate the workload.
options.analysis: You acknowledged Bob's frustration and proposed a solution to address the workload issue, demonstrating high empathy and good emotional perception.

options.text: I understand your point, Bob. Let's take a moment to consider if there are any tasks we can delegate or outsource.
options.analysis: You recognized Bob's concerns and suggested a practical approach to manage the workload, showing good self-regulation and social skills.

options.text: We've managed tough situations before, and we can do it again if we stay focused and work smart.
options.analysis: You focused on motivating the team by recalling past successes, demonstrating high motivation but lower empathy and emotional perception.
